content:
Okay, this may sound strange, but here is the real way to set fonts on Thunderbird. And I attached examples of my own setting of Calibri 14 as my default. Here goes: 

- in Tools>settings>general, set your default font.  - then click the advanced button. Notice the drop-down menu at top. It probably says 'latin' or 'other writing systems' - this is IMPORTANT:  - select 'latin from that menu, set your desired font and font size settings, click OK,  - select 'otherwritingsystems' from the drop-down menu and set the IDENTICAL settings to what you did for Latin, and then click OK. In attached screenshots you will see my latin and otherwritingsystem match.  Notice I also set monospace font. - and, if you have account set to compose HTML, then set that in tools>settings>composition to variable-width and medium font. (You would only change the HTML font setting if your intent is for recipient to receive your preferred font - not my personal recommendation.) - Set Sending Format to 'automatic'

With these settings, your compose window and your sent folders will match. And if you don't write HTML (e.g., bold, italic, color), none will be sent . If you do these settings once, your font will always be consistent. This does not protect you from someone sending you a message in some god-awful font with 30 pt size, but this does provide consistency.

NOTE: TB uses pixels, not points. If your font is very small, you may want to start with size 20 and then adjust.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks David, most helpful and looking good so far. 18 pixels worked well for me.

It's a pity though that the update made this necessary in the first place. I have recommended Thunderbird to many who are not at all tech-confident (including my mother!) and I doubt they would be able to make the adjustments. I hope a future update can address this.
creator: dxaxhill

content: Actually, I see this question often and that's why I have the prewritten answer. This has for years been the only way to get predictable and consistent font size. I'm pleased it worked well for you.
creator: davidsk

content: Select the account in the left pane of Account Settings, then look at Outgoing Server (SMTP) in the right pane. Is it pointing to the Default smtp? If Default doesn't appear there, you might be sending through one of the other smtp servers that has a different User Name. Since you only have one account, delete all the smtp servers except the Default server.

re :How do i get back to viewing emails in a box below the headers

Are you talking about the 'Message Pane' where content of an opened email displays? Nothing has changed for this. 'View' > 'Layout' > 'Message Pane' or use the key F8

Are you talking about the 'Message List' otherwise known as the 'Thread Pane' which displays the list of emails in folder ? It has column headers and displays in a sort of table view. Maybe you are viewing the new 'Cards View' ? In 'Message List Header' (it displays number of emails in folder and has the 'Quick Filter' button) - to the right of the Quick Filter button is a new icon - click on it to see options. Select 'Table View'.

This link to a Support Article may help you: https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/getting-started-thunderbird-main-window-supernova

content:
I have a BT mail account. As some people are still using 102.15.1, I'm still running a version of that using a BT Pop mail account. However, I'm running a beta 120.0b7 - I help out with debugging - that version has a BT Imap account.

I'm not getting any issues with prompts for password.

The one thing I did note with BT is that whatever password you have set up to access BT account - aka billing data etc has to be the same password as the one you use for webmail.

On one occasion, I decided to update my password for accessing my BT account - billing info etc - not webmail and suddenly I found Thunderbird had trouble getting emails and sending emails. So I logged into webmail and discovered I had to use the same password which I had set up for access the Account. I used to have two separate passwords as a security precaution, but now I cannot.

Then I updated the stored password in Thunderbird to match and all has been tickety boo since.

Both Pop and IMAP accounts are using this for the SMTP:

  • Description: my email address
  • Server name: mail.btinternet.com
  • Port: 465
  • Connection Security: SSL/TLS
  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name: full email address

Checked stored password:

  • Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Scroll to Passwords section
  • click on 'Saved Passwords' button
  • Click on 'Show Passwords' button

You should see two lines for the BT mail account. if Pop incoming: mailbox://mail.btinternet.com(mailbox://mail.btinternet.com) If imap incoming: imap://mail.btinternet.com(imap://mail.btinternet.com) outgoing smtp: smtp://mail.btinternet.com(smtp://mail.btinternet.com)

username will show full email address password should be correct password

Do you see both incoming and outgoing for your email address/username ? Is both username and password correct for incoming and outgoing smtp? Or is there only incoming - smtp is missing ?

content: The message means that the SMTP server must have the same email address as the one in your FROM line in the email message. Many email providers are getting tight on security and that is one of the tests to prevent spam. This usually happens when a person has several email accounts, yet uses the same SMTP server for all of them. You can fix this by going to account settings pane and scrolling down left side until you see 'Outgoing Servers SMTP' and then list the entries. There must be one for each email account and each one must have a matching email id to the account. You should also check to see if you are using any authentication such as password. For example, if you have three gmail accounts, you need three gmail SMTP servers, one for each email address. A simple way to keep track of them is to fill in the 'Description' field with unique indentifier for each one. Then, when looking at account settings pane, it will be easy to verify that you have set the right smtp server.
creator: davidsk

content: Okay there are multiple road runner emails configured with my ISP, but I only have my email address (wheeler@wi.rr.com) configured in Thunderbird on my computer. The FROM line is wheeler@wi.rr.com and the SMTP server is Smtp-server.wi.rr.com and the user name, when you click on edit under SMTP server, is wheeler. There isn't anywhere to enter an email address under the edit menu. When I click on account settings Outgoing Servers SMTP' there isn't a list of anything. It just lists default. My wife is getting the same error message when she tries to send emails on her computer. Her computer, like mine, only has her email address configured in Thunderbird. I see under SMTP server there is a button that says "add". I can add the other email addresses, but I do not know how to add additional SMTP servers. Thanks! Eric
creator: zzolson

content: The user name needs to be wheeler@wi.rr.com, not wheeler. You do not need to add another smtp server if your Thunderbird only has one email account. You need to have one smtp server for each account.
creator: davidsk

content: I did what you said and it worked!! Thanks for all your help!

content: You're very welcome.
creator: davidsk

content: Several email providers have made security tighter, causing the message. Check your SMTP server settings to ensure it shows the full email address in user name field and is using authentication and connection security. This error also appears if using ONE smtp server for TWO or more accounts (which is more common than one might think).
creator: davidsk
